title: [Problem Statement and Solution Overview]
content: - **Problem Statement ID:** SIH1569
**Theme:** Smart Automation
**Solution:** AquaTech - a nanohybrid paper-based chemiresistive sensor for detecting free chlorine in water
**Technology:** Graphene and PEDOT:PSS composite material for superior sensitivity and accuracy
**Integration:** Smartphone connectivity for instant, user-friendly digital results
image_desc: A close-up image of a paper-based sensor with a smartphone displaying a water quality result.
narration: Good day, everyone. I'm here to present our innovative solution for the Smart India Hackathon 2024, addressing the critical need for personalized testing kits to measure residual chlorine levels at water delivery points. Our team, AquaTech, has developed a portable, paper-based sensor that combines cutting-edge nanotechnology with smartphone integration for real-time water quality monitoring. We're tackling Problem Statement ID SIH1569, which falls under the Smart Automation theme. Our solution, AquaTech, is a nanohybrid paper-based chemiresistive sensor for detecting free chlorine in water. This innovative device utilizes a graphene and PEDOT:PSS composite material, offering superior sensitivity and accuracy. We've integrated it with smartphone connectivity for instant, user-friendly digital results, making it ideal for both urban and rural settings.

title: [Key Features and Problem Resolution]
content:
- **Features:**
    - Detects chlorine levels as low as 0.1 ppm, exceeding BIS 10500:2012 and WHO standards
    - Requires only 15 μL of sample, making testing effortless for households
    - AI-driven analysis improves accuracy and reduces false positives, providing results in just 5 minutes

**Problem Resolution:**
    - Democratizes water safety with lab-grade testing at a fraction of the cost
    - Empowers rural communities to conduct their own water quality assessments
    - Overcomes literacy barriers with clear visual indicators and voice-guided instructions
image_desc: A person using the paper-based sensor to test water, with a smartphone displaying the results.
narration: Our sensor boasts several key features. It can detect chlorine levels as low as 0.1 ppm, exceeding BIS 10500:2012 and WHO standards. It requires only 15 μL of sample, making testing effortless for households. AI-driven analysis improves accuracy and reduces false positives, providing results in just 5 minutes. We're addressing critical issues by democratizing water safety with lab-grade testing at a fraction of the cost, empowering rural communities to conduct their own water quality assessments, and overcoming literacy barriers with clear visual indicators and voice-guided instructions.

title: [Unique Value Propositions]
content: - **Simple, Standardized Fabrication Process:** Ensures consistency and scalability
**Portability:** On-site water quality monitoring
**No Sample Pre-processing:** Effortless testing
**High Specificity:** To residual chlorine with minimal interference from other ions
**Extremely Low Cost:** Estimated at just $0.03 per device
**Multilingual System:** Embedded using AI, enhancing accessibility across diverse populations
image_desc: A graphic illustrating the different stages of the sensor fabrication process.
narration: What sets our solution apart is a simple, standardized fabrication process, ensuring consistency and scalability. It's portable for on-site water quality monitoring and requires no sample pre-processing, making testing effortless. Our sensor boasts high specificity to residual chlorine with minimal interference from other ions. It's extremely low cost, estimated at just $0.03 per device. We've also implemented a multilingual system embedded using AI, enhancing accessibility across diverse populations.

title: [Technical Approach and Process Flow]
content:
- **Technical Approach:**
    1. Wax printing the sensor design on filter paper
    2. Applying the nanohybrid conductive ink as the sensing layer
    3. Adding conductive silver paint as electrodes
    4. Integrating with a custom-designed 3D-printed case for the electric readout system

**Process Flow:**
    - Signal capture and conversion by a designed circuit
    - Analog-to-digital conversion using an Arduino platform
    - Wireless transmission to a smartphone app for real-time display and analysis
image_desc: A diagram showing the technical approach and process flow of the AquaTech sensor.
narration: Our technical approach involves wax printing the sensor design on filter paper, applying the nanohybrid conductive ink as the sensing layer, adding conductive silver paint as electrodes, and integrating with a custom-designed 3D-printed case for the electric readout system. The process flow includes signal capture and conversion by a designed circuit, analog-to-digital conversion using an Arduino platform, and wireless transmission to a smartphone app for real-time display and analysis.
